text:
This video was almost never released because
I just kept overthinking it – Everything
about it

Was it good enough to be the first release
after my patreon launch, should I do more

animation, maybe I should reshoot it, why
do I feel this way?

Most of us have been in that position where
we’re overthinking something.

Thoughts are whisking through our minds
Stewing inside us
Slicing through the noise
And I started to wonder… why?

Did pondering things ever give us an advantage
as humans?
Did it help us become better problem solvers?

Or does overthinking everything just mean
our brain is broken?

So why do we have a tendency to overthink
things?
And how can we stop?

Now in everyday language we use overthinking
as an umbrella term to describe many different
thought processes.

There’s one type of overthinking called
rumination, where you obsessively overthink

why something happened or why you feel a certain
way.

You chew over the causes and consequences
of negative emotions, rather than solutions
or anything practical.

It’s similar to worry, though worry relates
to future events, while rumination is about
the past.

And some of the early research on rumination
happened in pretty extraordinary circumstances.

Imagine you’re a psychology student – you’ve
just started at Stanford in 1989 – and you

fill out a bunch of questionnaires for course
credit (because, since the dawn of time, students
will do anything for course credit).

These questionnaires, specifically, are about
depression and response styles and you do

them a few times so researchers can track
how you’re feeling.

Then – there’s a huge earthquake in San
Francisco.

61 people die, the Bay Bridge is damaged,
it’s pretty bad.
You’re, you know, shook.

So your professors keep giving you the questionnaires
to see which students would show the most

enduring symptoms of depression and post-traumatic
stress.

And they found those with ruminative response
styles were more likely to have high levels

of depressive and stress symptoms 7 weeks
after the earthquake.

It was some of the first strong evidence that
rumination exacerbates depression and post-traumatic
stress.

We also know it can increase negative thinking
and impair problem solving.

Now rumination was named after the process
that some mammals go through of chewing cud

to further break down plant matter and stimulate
digestion.

The problem in humans is that re-chewing your
thoughts can stimulate negativity because

our own biases creep in and affect how we
think – when you chew and chew and chew

over a trauma or natural disaster you remember
the worst parts over and over again – and
you get stuck in a negative feedback loop.

The best way to break this cycle is to be
aware when you’re ruminating

Mind wandering, emotional processing and problem
solving can be good types of overthinking.
Rumination is not.

Sometimes it’s hard to distinguish when
you’re just emotionally processing something
or if you’re ruminating.

It can be difficult to take a step back, but
try to pause and be aware of your own thoughts.

Rumination involves thought patterns that
are pessimistic and have a negative angle
to them.

Sometimes you almost trick yourself into thinking
through a problem and then you get stuck chewing
over the negativity.
So, some tips.

Find positive distractions: so do things you
find enjoyable, absorb you and are uplifting.

Watching YouTube - if you’re still here
- is a great option.
As is reading a book.
Fill your schedule - plan things.

The less time you have for negative thoughts,
the better.

And challenge yourself: trying to master a
task or solve a problem that will use all
of your brain power

One difference between you and a cow – well
there are many differences – but one is

that they need to ruminate to properly digest
their food – they need to ruminate to live.

But people don’t – and overthinking things
in a negative frame of mind can be harmful.

So, take care of yourself and leave ruminating
to
the cows.
